items.title: solid-state
items.summary: Solid-State Batteries# Solid-State Batteries: The Future? Solid-state batteries use a solid electrolyte instead of a liquid one. This allows for higher energy density (up to 500 Wh/kg) and improved safety as they are less flammable. items.content:
Solid-State Batteries# Solid-State Batteries: The Future?
Solid-state batteries use a solid electrolyte instead of a liquid one. This allows for higher energy density (up to 500 Wh/kg) and improved safety as they are less flammable.

## Why they matter
They could revolutionize EVs by extending range to 800+ miles and reducing charging time to 10 minutes.

## Challenges
Manufacturing costs are currently high, and dendrite formation remains a technical hurdle.

## Types of Solid Electrolytes
Oxides: Stable but brittle.Sulfides: High conductivity but sensitive to moisture.Polymers: Easy to process but lower conductivity.

items.title: li-ion
items.summary: Lithium-Ion Batteries# Lithium-Ion Batteries Explained Li-ion batteries use liquid electrolytes to move ions between cathode and anode. They are mature, cheap to manufacture ($130/kWh), and reliable. They power everything from phones to Teslas. The supply chain is established. Thermal runaway risks and lower theoretical energy density limits (approx 250 Wh/kg) compared to solid-state.
items.content:
Lithium-Ion Batteries# Lithium-Ion Batteries Explained
Li-ion batteries use liquid electrolytes to move ions between cathode and anode. They are mature, cheap to manufacture ($130/kWh), and reliable.

## Importance
They power everything from phones to Teslas. The supply chain is established.

## Downsides
Thermal runaway risks and lower theoretical energy density limits (approx 250 Wh/kg) compared to solid-state.

## Chemistry Types
NMC (Nickel Manganese Cobalt) offers high density. LFP (Lithium Iron Phosphate) is cheaper and safer but less dense.

items.title: battery-safety
items.summary: Solid state batteries are safer because they do not use flammable liquid electrolytes. Liquid electrolytes can catch fire at 60C. Solid electrolytes are stable up to 200C+.
items.content:
# Safety Comparison
Solid state batteries are safer because they do not use flammable liquid electrolytes.

## Thermal Runaway
Liquid electrolytes can catch fire at 60C. Solid electrolytes are stable up to 200C+.
